diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with autoimmune hemolysis, pericardial effusion, fever, and neuropsychiatric manifestations including delirium and psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily associated with streptococcal infections, rheumatic fever can cause fever, carditis including pericardial effusion, and can lead to Sydenham's chorea, which might manifest as psychosis or altered mental status.

diagnoses.name: Viral Myocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Viral infections can lead to myocarditis with pericardial effusion, fever, and in severe cases, can affect the central nervous system leading to delirium or psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Infective endocarditis can present with fever and can cause autoimmune hemolytic anemia through various mechanisms. It can also affect the central nervous system, leading to delirium or psychotic episodes.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder can cause a wide range of symptoms, including blood clots, miscarriage, autoimmune hemolysis, and potentially neurological complications like psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Certain medications can induce a lupus-like syndrome, presenting with symptoms like pericardial effusion, fever, and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Malignancies
diagnoses.rationale: Certain cancers can lead to autoimmune phenomena including hemolysis, pericardial effusion due to metastasis or paraneoplastic syndromes, and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder that involves both autoimmune hemolysis and thrombocytopenia, and can be associated with systemic autoimmune disorders that may lead to the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Primary Psychiatric Disorder
diagnoses.rationale: While less likely given the systemic symptoms, severe psychiatric disorders could primarily manifest with psychosis and potentially influence the perception or reporting of other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis can cause a wide range of symptoms depending on organ involvement, including pericardial effusion, fever, and in rare cases, central nervous system involvement leading to psychosis or delirium.

diagnoses: Tick-borne diseases (e.g., Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
Rickettsial diseases (including Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
Infectious Causes (e.g., Viral, Bacterial, Fungal infections)
Cancer (such as Lung Cancer or Lymphoma)
HELLP Syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelet count)
Schizophrenia (in the context of comorbid infection causing the listed symptoms)
Psychiatric disorders associated with systemic illness
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's Syndrome
Schizophrenia (in the context of autoimmune psychosis)
Psychiatric Disorders (e.g., Bipolar Disorder in manic phase)
Viral or Bacterial Infections leading to secondary autoimmune reactions
Systemic onset Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (Still's disease)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Felty's Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
Diabetes Mellitus – considering the hypoglycemia, which could indicate poor management of diabetes, and potentially related to the abnormal electrolytes.
Anxiety Disorders – which can sometimes manifest physically and could potentially explain obsessive-compulsive behavior, and in some cases, may contribute to dermatographism.
Primary Immunodeficiency – could account for recurrent infections leading to congestion and may indirectly contribute to abnormal electrolyte levels due to recurrent infections.
Chronic Kidney Disease – can lead to abnormal electrolytes and can indirectly cause hypoglycemia through impaired renal gluconeogenesis or medication effects.

Addison’s Disease (Adrenal Insufficiency) – can present with hypoglycemia, abnormal electrolytes, and potentially could contribute to the physical stress that exacerbates conditions like dermatographism.

Cushing's Syndrome – while typically associated with hyperglycemia, could theoretically lead to hypoglycemia through excessive use of insulin or other medications. It might also cause abnormal electrolytes.
Autoimmune Conditions (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus) – SLE can have a wide range of symptoms including dermatographism and can indirectly affect other parameters like electrolytes.
Thyroid Disorders (e.g., Hypothyroidism) – can potentially lead to obsessive-compulsive behavior and abnormal electrolytes. Thyroid disorders can also indirectly affect blood glucose levels.

Psychiatric Disorders (e.g., Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder) – directly accounts for obsessive-compulsive behavior and can also lead to stress responses that might influence electrolytes and potentially, though rarely, dermatographism.

Mast Cell Disorders – directly related to dermatographism and can also cause a wide range of systemic symptoms, including changes in blood sugar levels and possibly leading to hypoglycemia during episodes of mast cell activation.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder where mast cells are abnormally increased in multiple organs including the skin, bone marrow, and gastrointestinal tract. It can lead to flushing, gastrointestinal symptoms, and an increased risk of aneurysms due to the effects of mast cell mediators.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue, leading to features such as tall stature, long limbs, hypermobility of the joints, and an increased risk of developing aneurysms, particularly in the aorta.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues, causing symptoms like hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and fragile tissues. Some types may present with an increased risk of aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Lysosomal Acid Lipase Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder that can lead to lipid accumulation in various tissues, potentially causing hepatosplenomegaly, hyperlipidemia, and manifestation of cutaneous problems like onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that leads to the overproduction of red blood cells. It can cause a wide range of symptoms including basophilia, and with increased blood viscosity, may indirectly be involved with the pathogenesis of aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the bone marrow and blood, leading to increased levels of white blood cells including basophils. It can cause a wide range of symptoms depending on the stage of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Hyper IgD Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A hereditary inflammatory disorder characterized by recurrent fever, lymphadenopathy, abdominal pain, and skin rashes. Flushing may occur during febrile episodes.

diagnoses.name: Loeys-Dietz Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder similar to Marfan Syndrome, affecting connective tissue throughout the body. It comes with a heightened risk for aneurysms, arterial tortuosity, and aortic dissection, along with hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Fabry Disease
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that results from the build-up of globotriaosylceramide due to the deficiency of the enzyme α-galactosidase A, leading to a wide range of symptoms including angiokeratomas, renal dysfunction, and could be associated with an increased risk of aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition where a carcinoid tumor secretes serotonin or other chemicals into the bloodstream, causing flushing, diarrhea, and rarely, heart problems. Flushing is a prominent symptom.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Metabolic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A cluster of conditions that occur together, increasing your risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes. These conditions include increased blood pressure, high blood sugar, excess body fat around the waist, and abnormal cholesterol levels. The presence of three or more of these conditions constitutes a diagnosis of metabolic syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin D Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vitamin D deficiency is common in patients with osteoporosis and can contribute to decreased calcium absorption, bone loss, and worsening of osteoporotic changes. It may also indirectly contribute to hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Hypothyroidism can lead to a variety of health problems, such as obesity, joint pain, infertility, and heart disease. It can also be associated with hair loss (alopecia) and can indirectly worsen obstructive sleep apnea due to weight gain.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by hormonal imbalance that can affect women in their reproductive years. PCOS may lead to hypertension, weight gain, and hair growth or loss. Though not directly associated with osteoporosis or periodontal disease, the associated weight gain can exacerbate obstructive sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs from exposure to high cortisol levels for a long time. The syndrome can lead to hypertension, osteoporosis, and alopecia. It may also exacerbate obstructive sleep apnea due to weight gain.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose). Both type 1 and type 2 diabetes can lead to hypertension. Type 2 diabetes is also associated with an increased risk of periodontal disease and may worsen the complications of obstructive sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause a wide variety of systemic symptoms. It's associated with osteoporosis and can indirectly affect the severity of periodontal disease due to the body's decreased capacity to fight infection.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time. It can lead to hypertension and makes patients more susceptible to bone density loss, thus contributing to osteoporosis. Kidney disease can also involve alterations in hair texture and loss.

diagnoses.name: Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which one or more of the parathyroid glands produce too much parathyroid hormone, which can result in the body taking calcium from the bones, thereby weakening them (osteoporosis), and can also contribute to hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Sleep-Related Breathing Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders characterized by abnormal respiration during sleep, the most common of which is obstructive sleep apnea. These disorders can have systemic effects, including hypertension due to the stress it puts on the cardiovascular system and may indirectly affect bone health.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include fatigue, cold sensitivity, and cognitive difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to produce too many red blood cells. Symptoms may include headache, dizziness, and a ruddy complexion.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease affecting the brain and spinal cord, leading to weakness, coordination and balance difficulties, and cognitive issues.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. It can cause fatigue and pallor.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the skin, joints, and organs. Symptoms can be wide-ranging.

diagnoses.name: Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP)
diagnoses.description: A rare blood disorder that can cause blood clots to form in small blood vessels throughout the body. Symptoms may include fatigue, pallor, and neurological issues.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands responsible for keeping the eyes, mouth, and other parts of the body moist and lubricated.

diagnoses.name: Vocal Cord Polyps
diagnoses.description: Noncancerous growths on one or both of the vocal cords. Can cause hoarseness and laryngitis.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia, a condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells. Iron deficiency anemia is due to insufficient iron.

diagnoses: Asthma (for wheezing, considering other diagnoses for the remaining symptoms)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Cushing's syndrome can cause easy bruising, increased appetite, and hypertension due to excessive cortisol levels. Although not a direct cause, the stress related to Cushing's may contribute to Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic kidney disease can lead to hypertension and contribute to cardiovascular health issues, including Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. It indirectly can affect the body’s ability to metabolize and thus may present with symptoms like easy bruising and hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor of the adrenal gland tissue causing an overproduction of hormones that can lead to symptoms such as hypertension, headache, and increased appetite. It can also increase the risk of cardiac issues.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.reasoning: This condition leads to an increased volume of red blood cells, which can cause hypertension and headache. Easy bruising is also a symptom due to the increased pressure in blood vessels. Its stress on the cardiovascular system may influence Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Essential Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Like Polycythemia Vera, Essential Thrombocythemia is a rare disorder that can cause high blood pressure, headaches, and easy bruising due to an excessively high platelet count, which could indirectly affect cardiac health.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: This is a bleeding disorder that causes easy bruising. While not directly causing increased appetite or Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, patients with significant cardiovascular stress might experience complications impacting the heart.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Hypothyroidism can sometimes cause increased appetite, and while less common, it can also contribute to hypertension. Easy bruising isn't a hallmark symptom but can appear in severe or untreated cases.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain types of leukemia can cause easy bruising, an increased appetite due to metabolic demands, and a headache. Hypertension is less direct but can occur in severe cases due to kidney damage.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE can cause easy bruising and, in severe cases, contribute to cardiovascular diseases, potentially impacting heart health in the form of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. It can also lead to hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Congestive Heart Failure
diagnoses.reasoning: While more of a resultant condition, congestive heart failure can be linked with symptoms like hypertension and may be a consequence of chronic Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Headaches and increased appetite are less directly associated but can appear in the overall clinical picture.

diagnoses: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) / Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS)

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by the coexistence of several endocrine gland insufficiencies, which may present with the given symptoms due to autoimmune destruction of the glands.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder affecting phagocytes, leading to an inability to destroy certain bacteria and fungi, causing increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone, which can cause alopecia and increase susceptibility to infection due to lowered immunity.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoproliferative Disorders
diagnoses.description: These disorders, including lymphoma, can cause generalized symptoms such as sweats, and the immune dysregulation can lead to increased infections and eosinophilia.

diagnoses.name: Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder characterized by the disturbed development of functional T cells and B cells caused by numerous genetic mutations, leading to severe infections.

diagnoses.name: Hyper-IgE Syndrome (Job's Syndrome)
diagnoses.description: A rare immunodeficiency characterized by high levels of serum IgE, eosinophilia, recurrent skin and lung infections, and dermatological problems like alopecia.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus significantly weakens the immune system, leading to a higher risk of infections, and can also cause thyroid dysfunction and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Although primarily known for causing anemia, severe iron deficiency can affect the immune system, leading to increased susceptibility to infection and potentially affecting thyroid function.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system, which can cause symptoms like night sweats, increased susceptibility to infections, and potentially impact the thyroid.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the endocrine system and skin, causing a wide range of symptoms such as alopecia, hypothyroidism, and increased risk of infections.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Hypermobility is a common feature.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing sudden swelling of areas of the body, potentially including the eyes and other parts of the face. These swellings can occur in response to injury, surgical procedures, or stress.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of the body including joints (hypermobility issues), skin (rash), and eyes (irritation).

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue, leading to features like tall stature, long limbs, and finger hypermobility. Eye problems including lens dislocation can cause irritation.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth. It may also cause joint pain and affect other areas of the body.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition in which mast cells release too much of their content, leading to severe allergy symptoms, potentially including angioedema and irritation of mucous membranes.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. While not directly causing the listed symptoms, hormonal imbalances can lead to mood lability.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inner ear disorder that can cause episodes of vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness in the ear.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that cannot be explained by any underlying medical condition. Symptoms may worsen with physical or mental activity but don't improve with rest.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that cannot be explained by any underlying medical condition. Symptoms might include difficulty focusing, lymphadenopathy, and immune system abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, often causing lymphadenopathy and dermatographism among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that form lumps known as granulomas. It often affects the lungs and lymph nodes, leading to dyspnea and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacteria, spread by ticks. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including lymphadenopathy and, in later stages, neurological and cardiac symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer originating from white blood cells called lymphocytes. Symptoms include enlarged lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy), fatigue, and occasionally, dermatographism.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A diverse group of blood cancers that include any kind of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, dyspnea, and generalized weakness.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A controversial and often misunderstood diagnosis characterized by persistent symptoms such as fatigue, musculoskeletal pain, and cognitive difficulties following treatment for Lyme disease.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland is overactive and produces excessive amounts of thyroid hormones, leading to symptoms like fatigue, increased heart rate, and potentially vision issues.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition in which mast cells release too much of their content into the bloodstream or tissues, leading to a wide range of symptoms including dermatographism and potentially lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. It can cause a wide array of symptoms, including issues with vision focus and, in some cases, dyspnea.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C with extrahepatic manifestations

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.reasoning: Common cold or flu can trigger a wide range of symptoms including hypersensitivity reactions (like hives), digestive issues (diarrhea), and respiratory symptoms (chest pain from coughing, epistaxis from nasal irritation). Word-finding difficulty can be a feature of the general malaise and cognitive disruption sometimes observed with systemic viral infections.

An allergic reaction could potentially explain hypersensitivity reactions, diarrhea (if the allergen was ingested), and epistaxis (from nose blowing or sinus pressure). Word-finding difficulty is less directly associated but could relate to the stress or distraction from other symptoms.

Stress and anxiety can induce or exacerbate symptoms like chest pain (from muscle tension or hyperventilation), hypersensitivity reactions (psychosomatic urticaria), diarrhea (from gastrointestinal distress), and cognitive issues like word-finding difficulty. Epistaxis could be stress-related or incidental.

Various medications can cause side effects including chest pain, diarrhea, hypersensitivity reactions, and cognitive disturbances. Epistaxis could be related to anticoagulant use or drugs causing nasal dryness or irritation.

Conditions like lupus could explain a wide range of symptoms due to inflammation and autoimmunity affecting various tissues: skin (hypersensitivity reactions), nervous system (word-finding difficulty), gastrointestinal tract (diarrhea), and possibly leading to chest pain or epistaxis from vasculitis or other complications.

Primary symptom is diarrhea, but patients can also experience systemic symptoms like chest pain (from associated respiratory or cardiac complications), hypersensitivity reactions (skin rashes), and cognitive issues like word-finding difficulty during flares. Epistaxis could be incidental or related to coagulation alterations.

MCAS can cause a wide array of symptoms including hypersensitivity reactions, diarrhea, cognitive disturbances (like word-finding difficulty), chest pain, and possibly epistaxis due to its effects on various body systems and inflammatory processes.

Certain neurological conditions (for example, multiple sclerosis) can present with cognitive symptoms like word-finding difficulty, while also potentially affecting other areas leading to chest pain (from muscle spasms or nerve pain), hypersensitivity reactions (nerve-related), and gastrointestinal symptoms (diarrhea). Epistaxis is less directly related.

Depending on the location and type, cancer can manifest in diverse symptoms including chest pain (lung, esophageal), diarrhea (colorectal), hypersensitivity reactions (cutaneous lymphomas or paraneoplastic syndromes), cognitive issues (brain tumors), and possibly epistaxis as a less common symptom or related to treatment effects.

With its effect on the immune system, HIV/AIDS can cause a broad spectrum of symptoms including diarrhea, chest pain (from opportunistic infections), hypersensitivity reactions (including those to medications), and cognitive disturbances. Epistaxis could occur due to low platelet counts or opportunistic infections affecting the nasal passages.

diagnoses: Connective Tissue Diseases (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often features symptoms such as dry eyes, which could exacerbate conditions leading to urinary tract infections due to overall dryness and contribute to hypersensitivity reactions. Delayed puberty is less directly associated but could be related to broader autoimmune dysregulation.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: Another autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including hypersensitivity reactions and renal issues that may predispose an individual to urinary tract infections. Dry eyes can also be a feature due to associated Sjögren's syndrome, and angioedema could be a manifestation as well. Its systemic nature may impact developmental milestones like puberty.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A genetic condition primarily causing angioedema but can have varied systemic effects. While not directly linked to delayed puberty, urinary tract infections, or dry eyes, its complex interplay with the immune system might contribute to a broader symptomatology in some cases.

diagnoses.name: Turner Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A chromosomal disorder affecting females, leading to delayed puberty due to ovarian insufficiency. Patients may also have kidney malformations that predispose them to urinary tract infections. Dry eyes could potentially correlate with this condition due to associated autoimmune diseases.

diagnoses.name: Klinefelter Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic condition affecting males, characterized by an extra X chromosome that can lead to delayed puberty. While less directly associated with the other symptoms, individuals with this syndrome may experience a broader range of health issues.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: This group of disorders disturbs the body's ability to fight infections, potentially leading to frequent urinary tract infections. Some of these disorders might also cause angioedema and hypersensitivity reactions. Delayed puberty can occasionally be a secondary effect due to the chronic illness impact on overall health.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Chronic diabetes can lead to a suppressed immune system, making individuals more susceptible to infections such as urinary tract infections. Dry eyes are a common symptom of diabetes, and while delayed puberty is less common, poorly controlled diabetes can affect growth and development.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Thyroid hormones are crucial for development and metabolic regulation. Hypothyroidism can lead to delayed puberty. It can also make individuals more prone to infections, including urinary tract infections, and contribute to dry skin and possibly dry eyes.

diagnoses.name: IgA Vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that can cause a hypersensitivity reaction throughout the body, potentially affecting the kidneys (which could predispose to urinary tract infections) and causing angioedema. Delayed puberty is less directly related but could occur alongside chronic illness.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: A disorder that reduces the immune system's ability to fight infections, leading to an increased risk of developing urinary tract infections and potentially contributing to hypersensitivity reactions. Dry eyes might be associated due to co-existing autoimmune disorders. Delayed puberty can sometimes be a feature due to the impact of chronic illness on growth and development.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, potentially leading to a variety of symptoms, including fatigue, weight gain, and mood swings.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A common and serious medical illness that negatively affects how you feel, the way you think, and how you act, possibly contributing to decreased libido and changes in appetite.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Rhinosinusitis
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by inflammation of the nose and sinus cavities lasting more than 12 weeks. This condition is often associated with decreased sense of taste (dysgeusia) and increased sensitivity to environmental triggers.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose). Diabetes can affect your body's ability to regulate appetite, leading to increased hunger.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing itchy, watery eyes, sneezing, and other similar symptoms. Chronic conditions can lead to decreased sense of taste and overall fatigue or malaise.

diagnoses.name: Stress
diagnoses.description: The body's reaction to any change that requires an adjustment or response. Stress can affect the body physically and mentally, leading to symptoms such as increased appetite or decreased libido.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A sleep disorder that involves repeated stopping and starting of breathing. Individuals often experience daytime fatigue and mood disturbances, possibly affecting libido and sensory perceptions.

diagnoses.name: Drug Side Effects
diagnoses.description: Certain medications can cause side effects including decreased libido, dysgeusia, and increased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. Symptoms can include weight gain and fatigue, which could indirectly affect libido and appetite.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by feelings of worry, anxiety, or fear that are strong enough to interfere with one's daily activities. Symptoms may include changes in libido and eating habits.

diagnoses: Secondary Immunodeficiency Due to External Causes (e.g., medications, environmental factors)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergy-related condition that leads to swollen, inflamed nasal passages and symptoms such as sneezing, itchiness, and a blocked or runny nose.

diagnoses.name: Atopic Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic skin condition causing itchy, inflamed skin, possibly contributing to conditions like dermatographism.

diagnoses.name: Viral Upper Respiratory Infection
diagnoses.description: A common viral infection affecting the nose, throat, airways, sinuses, and ears, potentially leading to cough, sinusitis, and ear infections.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition involving the airways in the lungs, leading to difficulty breathing, coughing, and wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Refractive Error
diagnoses.description: A vision problem that causes blurred vision due to the shape of the eye not bending light correctly, leading to difficulty focusing.

diagnoses.name: Eustachian Tube Dysfunction
diagnoses.description: A condition affecting the tube that connects the middle ear to the back of the nose, leading to pressure changes, ear pain, and potentially contributing to otitis externa.

diagnoses.name: Acute Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the sinuses that can cause congestion, facial pain, and cough.

diagnoses.name: Environmental Allergies
diagnoses.description: Reactions to allergens found in the indoor or outdoor environment, leading to symptoms such as sinusitis, cough, and ear problems.

diagnoses.name: Contact Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A type of inflammation of the skin resulting from direct contact with an irritant or allergen, potentially explaining dermatographism.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs, symptoms include breathing difficulty, cough, mucus (sputum) production, and wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.description: An open sore that develops on the inside lining of the stomach, upper small intestine, or esophagus, often linked to Helicobacter pylori infection or long-term use of NSAIDs. Common symptoms may include stomach pain, nausea, and, less commonly, changes in appetite which might relate to dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where stomach contents come back up into the esophagus leading to various symptoms. In some cases, the acid may reach the mouth, causing oral pain or an unpleasant taste (dysgeusia).

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing chronic inflammation in the blood vessels throughout your body, including the mouth. This condition can cause oral ulcers and might disrupt normal taste perception (dysgeusia). Given its systemic nature, it could lead to abdominal pain as well.

diagnoses.name: Crohn's Disease
diagnoses.description: A type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus. Symptoms often include abdominal pain, ulcers, including possible mouth ulcers, and it may indirectly cause dysgeusia due to nutritional deficiencies or the presence of sores.

diagnoses.name: Ischemic Bowel Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when part of the bowel loses its blood supply, leading to tissue death and symptoms such as sudden abdominal pain. Given its relationship with blood flow, patients with atherosclerosis are at increased risk.

diagnoses.name: Oral Lichen Planus
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory condition affecting the mucous membranes inside your mouth. Oral lichen planus may manifest as painful mouth ulcers and could alter taste sensation (dysgeusia).

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, presenting with symptoms including abdominal pain and potential mouth ulcers, as well as contributing to dysgeusia through nutritional deficiencies.

diagnoses.name: Gastric Cancer
diagnoses.description: A disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the lining of the stomach, leading to symptoms such as stomach pain, nausea, and potentially including dysgeusia or oral pain if the cancer has spread or due to the side effects of treatment.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: Although primarily a lung infection, tuberculosis can be extra-pulmonary and affect the gastrointestinal tract, potentially causing abdominal pain, ulcers, including oral ulcers, and could affect taste senses.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin Deficiencies (B12, Zinc)
diagnoses.description: Deficiencies in vitamins such as B12 or minerals like zinc can lead to a range of symptoms including oral pain, taste alterations (dysgeusia), and if severe, could contribute to the development of mouth ulcers.

diagnoses: Osteoporosis (considering osteopenia as a potential precursor)
Toxic Effects of Venomous Bites or Stings
Immune Dysregulation, Polyendocrinopathy, Enteropathy, X-linked Syndrome
Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck
Heart Diseases (such as Coronary Artery Disease)
Hyperthyroidism (can cause anxiety and heart symptoms, though typically associated with weight loss, rare cases can present differently)
Medication Side Effects (certain medications can induce seizures, weight gain, and other symptoms)
Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS; more specific to females, can cause weight gain, anxiety)
Metabolic Syndrome (a cluster of conditions including increased blood pressure, high blood sugar, excess body fat around the waist, and abnormal cholesterol or triglyceride levels)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Secondary Polycythemia due to Hypoxia or Hypoventilation
Vitamin Deficiency (e.g., Vitamin K, Vitamin C, Vitamin D)
Coagulation Disorder (e.g., Hemophilia, Von Willebrand Disease)

diagnoses.name: Major Depression Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition, which may worsen with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Blepharitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the eyelids in which they become red, irritated, and itchy with dandruff-like scales forming on the eyelashes. It is a common cause of irritated eyes and can lead to blepharospasm.

diagnoses.name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A brain disorder marked by an ongoing pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development.

diagnoses.name: Dry Eye Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the eyes do not produce enough tears or the tears evaporate too quickly. This leaves the eyes dry, red, and irritated.

diagnoses.name: Viral Laryngitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the larynx (voice box) from a viral infection. It is characterized by symptoms such as a hoarse voice or temporary loss of voice and may be associated with a cold or flu.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: An anxiety disorder characterized by chronic anxiety, exaggerated worry, and tension, even when there is little or nothing to provoke it.

diagnoses.name: Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD)
diagnoses.description: A type of depression that's related to changes in seasons — SAD begins and ends at about the same times every year. If you're like most people with SAD, your symptoms start in the fall and continue into the winter months, sapping your energy and making you feel moody.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Depression
diagnoses.description: A type of depression that is a direct response to a significant stressor or life event.

diagnoses.name: Benign Essential Blepharospasm
diagnoses.description: A condition causing involuntary blinking or spasm of the eyelids. Blepharospasm is often associated with dry eyes, eye irritation, and emotional tension.

diagnoses: COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease) with acute exacerbation
Ectopic pregnancy (in females of reproductive age)
Systemic allergic reactions to drugs or toxins
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Common Cold or Upper Respiratory Infection
Asthma (reactive airway disease, wheezing as a symptom)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Psychogenic pruritus (related to stress or psychological conditions)

diagnoses.description: Reactions to allergens that could cause skin and eye irritation, gastrointestinal symptoms, and sometimes cardiovascular symptoms like fainting.
An infection causing inflammation of the stomach and intestines that can lead to symptoms like diarrhea, and sometimes systemic symptoms.
A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can impair breathing, cause a sudden drop in blood pressure and symptoms like diarrhea and skin rashes.
An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food, causing various symptoms including gastrointestinal issues, skin reactions, and potentially anaphylaxis.
Chronic inflammation of the digestive tract that can cause diarrhea. Extraintestinal manifestations may include skin rashes and eye problems.
Adverse reactions to medications that can manifest as skin rashes (pruritus), gastrointestinal symptoms (diarrhea), and sometimes anaphylaxis (leading to syncope).
A common disorder affecting the large intestine. Symptoms include cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea or constipation, or both.
A red, itchy rash caused by direct contact with a substance or an allergic reaction to it, sometimes accompanied by systemic symptoms if severe.
Inflammation or infection of the outer membrane of the eyeball and the inner eyelid (conjunctival injections), which can be allergic, viral, or bacterial in origin.
A condition caused by excessive mast cell activation, which can result in a wide variety of symptoms, including skin, gastrointestinal, cardiovascular (syncope), and ocular symptoms.

diagnoses: Allergic reaction to food or medication
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Asthma (with gastrointestinal symptoms and allergy-related nasal congestion)
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) exacerbation with gastrointestinal symptoms
Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) with esophageal involvement

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden weakness, face drooping, and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines with aura are a type of headache accompanied by sensory disturbances called aura. These disturbances can include visual changes, speech or language difficulties, and motor weakness. Phonophobia (sensitivity to sound) is a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor involves abnormal cell growth within the brain. Depending on the tumor's location, it can cause headaches, speech problems, weakness, and neurological deficits.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including difficulties with speech, weakness, and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: ALS is a type of motor neuron disease that causes the death of neurons controlling voluntary muscles. Symptoms can include difficulty speaking (dysarthria), muscle weakness, and more severe neurological impairments as it progresses.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: A TIA, or mini-stroke, occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is temporarily disrupted. Symptoms, including aphasia and weakness, are similar to those of a stroke but usually last only a few minutes to a few hours before disappearing completely.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. It can cause severe headaches, phonophobia, and neurological deficits, including problems with speech and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system disorder where brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Some forms can also manifest with dysarthria, aphasia, and motor weakness post-seizure.

diagnoses.name: Primary Progressive Aphasia
diagnoses.description: This rare neurological syndrome involves progressive language capabilities loss while other mental functions remain intact. Initially, it might present with speech difficulties and gradually progress to more severe aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection. Symptoms can include headache, neurological deficits, speech problems, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A sudden disabling attack or loss of consciousness caused by an interruption in the flow of blood to the brain, especially through thrombosis. Symptoms can include sudden numbness, weakness, especially on one side of the body, confusion, trouble speaking, and loss of balance or coordination.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. It affects nerves leading to your extremities as well as nerves controlling involuntary functions. Symptoms include numbness, tingling, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A result of damage to your peripheral nerves, often causes weakness, numbness and pain, usually in your hands and feet, but it can also affect other areas and body functions including digestion and urination.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Transverse Myelitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of both sides of one section of the spinal cord, resulting in various neurological symptoms including weakness, sensory alterations, and autonomic dysfunction. The onset of symptoms can be sudden or gradual.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of B12 can lead to neurological problems and pernicious anemia. Symptoms include weakness, numbness, tingling, and balance problems.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that's preceded or accompanied by sensory warning signs such as flashes of light, blind spots, tingling in the arms and legs, and difficulty speaking. The aura can mimic the sensory changes seen with stroke but typically resolves without long-term effects.

diagnoses.name: Cervical Spondylosis
diagnoses.description: A condition involving changes to the bones, discs, and joints of the neck as a result of aging. Symptoms can include pain and stiffness in the neck, numbness and weakness in the arms, hands, and fingers; trouble walking, loss of balance, or weakness in the legs.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi s.l. Symptoms can include rash, fever, chills, fatigue, joint aches, and neurological disorders such as numbness, tingling, or weakness.

diagnoses: Brain Tumor (particularly those affecting the posterior fossa or brainstem)
Miller Fisher Syndrome (a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Evans syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immunothrombocytopenia)
Infectious Diseases (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B, and Lyme Disease)
Infectious Diseases (e.g., certain bacterial or viral infections that can cause a similar constellation of symptoms)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE can manifest with a wide range of symptoms including alopecia, arthritis (such as synovitis), and hematologic abnormalities including lymphopenia. Vasculitis that can cause mononeuritis multiplex may also occur.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: Characterized primarily by synovitis, Rheumatoid Arthritis can also lead to systemic features including skin manifestations and, less commonly, hematologic abnormalities such as lymphopenia.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily affecting the exocrine glands, Sjögren's Syndrome can feature systemic manifestations including arthritis (synovitis), neuropathy (including mononeuritis multiplex), and hematologic abnormalities like lymphopenia.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.reason: This condition can cause skin changes including telangiectasias and alopecia. Vasculitis leading to mononeuritis multiplex and features such as synovitis can occur.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.reason: While known for muscle and skin involvement, dermatomyositis can show features such as nonscarring alopecia, telangiectasias, and potentially mononeuritis multiplex due to vasculitis.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Wegener's)
diagnoses.reason: This condition features granulomatous inflammation and vasculitis, which can lead to synovitis, mononeuritis multiplex, and, rarely, hematologic manifestations like lymphopenia.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss Syndrome)
diagnoses.reason: Characterized by asthma, eosinophilia, and vasculitis. It can lead to mononeuritis multiplex, and possibly synovitis or skin manifestations like nodules or rash, which could potentially include telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.reason: A condition that features overlap of symptoms from systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including synovitis, alopecia, and less commonly, hematologic abnormalities such as lymphopenia.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.reason: This condition can cause a variety of symptoms depending on the vessels involved, including skin manifestations like nodules or ulcers that may mimic telangiectasias, mononeuritis multiplex, and occasionally features like myalgia or arthritis.

diagnoses.name: Undifferentiated Connective Tissue Disease (UCTD)
diagnoses.reason: An entity characterized by signs and symptoms suggestive of a connective tissue disease (like synovitis, alopecia, or telangiectasias) but that does not fulfill the criteria for a specific disease. Lymphopenia can be a feature here as well.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Infectious Diseases (e.g., Hepatitis B or C related vasculitis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.details: A chronic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation of various parts of the body. It can manifest with discoid rash, hematologic abnormalities including hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, and musculoskeletal symptoms like synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also have systemic manifestations including skin manifestations and hematologic abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.details: A group of autoimmune diseases that cause the skin and connective tissues to harden and tighten. Telangiectasias and systemic symptoms including hematologic abnormalities are common.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory muscle disease characterized by muscle weakness and skin rash. Although telangiectasias are more specifically associated with dermatomyositis than some of the other diagnoses, hematologic abnormalities can also be present.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.details: A rare autoimmune disorder that has features of three other connective tissue diseases: lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. This includes skin manifestations such as telangiectasias, hematologic abnormalities, and synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immune Thrombocytopenia
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder that can present with thrombocytopenia. While this condition primarily affects platelets, patients may exhibit other autoimmune symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia, potentially alongside other autoimmune phenomena.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune condition characterized by thrombosis and pregnancy complications, often together with hematologic abnormalities like thrombocytopenia. Skin manifestations can include livedo reticularis, which could be mistaken for or co-exist with telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria
diagnoses.details: A rare, acquired life-threatening disease of the blood characterized by the destruction of red blood cells (hemolytic anemia), blood clots (thrombosis), and impaired bone marrow function. Not directly related to the listed symptoms but could present with hematologic abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Vasculitis
diagnoses.details: A manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) where there is inflammation of the blood vessels. This can lead to skin manifestations such as rash and telangiectasias, joint pain, and hematologic abnormalities.

diagnoses: Vasculitis secondary to infections (e.g., Hepatitis C)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with ITP)
Vasculitis (e.g., CNS Vasculitis associated with systemic diseases)

diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs.
A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet.
A rare disorder that causes inflammation of the blood vessels in your nose, sinuses, throat, lungs, and kidneys.
An uncommon disorder that causes inflammation of small blood vessels, potentially affecting various organs including the kidneys, lungs, and nerves.
An autoimmune disease that affects the glands responsible for tears and saliva. It can lead to dry eyes, dry mouth, and joint pain.
A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, leading to various symptoms including mouth sores, genital sores, eye inflammation, and skin rashes.
An autoimmune condition characterized by asthma, high levels of eosinophils, and inflammation of blood vessels.
A mild to moderate anemia that occurs with chronic, or long term, medical conditions such as infection, inflammation, or cancer.
An autoimmune disorder that may combine features of lupus, scleroderma, polymyositis, and rheumatoid arthritis.
A group of disorders characterized by an autoimmune attack against the body's own red blood cells, leading to their destruction.

diagnoses: Infectious Diseases (e.g., Hepatitis C associated with cryoglobulinemia)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with cutaneous manifestations like lichen planus and a psoriasiform rash, go along with hematologic abnormalities such as hemolytic anemia, and immune dysregulation leading to lymphopenia.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known for muscle weakness and a characteristic rash, dermatomyositis can occasionally present with features resembling lichen planus and can be associated with hemolytic anemia and lymphopenia due to autoimmune activity.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease is characterized by features of several connective tissue diseases including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Symptoms can include skin manifestations similar to lichen planus, hematological disorders like hemolytic anemia, and lymphopenia.

diagnoses.name: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: DRESS syndrome can include skin eruptions akin to a psoriasiform rash or lichen planus, hematological disturbances like hemolytic anemia, and lymphopenia as part of its presentation.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Certain types of lymphoma can present with skin lesions that may mimic lichen planus or a psoriasiform rash, alongside symptoms like lymphopenia and hemolytic anemia due to bone marrow infiltration or autoimmune reactions.

diagnoses.name: Graft versus Host Disease (GvHD)
diagnoses.rationale: In patients with a history of transplantation, GvHD can present with skin changes including lichen planus-like eruptions and a psoriasiform rash, as well as blood anomalies like lymphopenia and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This condition involves abnormal lymphocyte survival leading to lymphoproliferation, autoimmune manifestations such as hemolytic anemia, and potentially lymphopenia after extensive lymphocyte activation and death.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis C
diagnoses.rationale: Chronic hepatitis C infection can be associated with extra-hepatic manifestations including lichen planus and hematological disorders like hemolytic anemia. Immune dysregulation can also lead to lymphopenia.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV infection can present with a wide range of dermatological manifestations including lichen planus, as well as hematological anomalies like hemolytic anemia and lymphopenia due to immune system compromise.

diagnoses.name: Parvovirus B19 infection
diagnoses.rationale: Parvovirus B19 can cause aplastic crises in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders, potentially manifesting with skin changes similar to lichen planus. The infection itself can cause temporary lymphopenia.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's granulomatosis)
Viral Infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
Viral infections (e.g., Coxsackievirus, echovirus causing pericarditis)
Cancer (e.g., lymphoma can cause pericardial effusion)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
